reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s treatment of future “moral catastrophes” (esp. digital rights and space resources) as mainly stemming from principled moral error, arguing instead that institutional capture by compute/power holders is the dominant generator of bad outcomes. This is only moderately central to the essay’s core thesis (“mostly-great futures are a narrow target” / eutopia is fragile): capture does not really refute narrow-target/fussiness claims and may even reinforce them, and the essay explicitly brackets navigation/steering as the next paper’s topic. As a refutation of what it attacks, it is somewhat weakened because the paper already gestures at self-interest, motivated cognition, and political systems preventing ‘right’ views from winning (so capture is partially ‘priced in’), and because it offers little concrete argument for why capture dominates vs. philosophical fussiness rather than being an additional factor. Relevance is high because power concentration/institutional failure is a core Forethought concern (Tier 1/2) and it usefully highlights an interaction: “better futures” deliberation could be co-opted and become legitimating veneer. Overall, it’s a plausible reframing but not a strong undermining of this specific essay’s main claim.
title: Institutional capture undermines the paper's moral framing
